F190D2CD6D294ECE86B24A47F6FB8C5F.description: ESOLIII.F.46: demonstrate understanding of subtleties of meaning in a variety of level appropriate works, including idiomatic expressions and figurative language

1C1E177CFEBE4DB0B26688A044686A51.description: ESOLIII.F.45: determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on reading and context clues

18125E2D649142C99AD2B5BFAD2B174C.description: ESOLIII.F.44: acquire and accurately use general academic and domain-specific words and phrases; gather vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase important to comprehension or expression

9B23829AE22D4D59AC921C445F706B5B.description: ESOLIII.F.43.a: use visual cues to determine the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words on familiar and new topics

375A4DBC1C65472FBADD96086C446893.description: ESOLIII.F.43: use knowledge of morphology (e.g., affixes, Greek and Latin roots), context, reference materials to determine and learn the meaning of new words

F4AC813C096140B19D9677678C97C651.description: ESOLIII.E.42: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing

32DAD4A443D24D21BD91D8D6322653AD.description: ESOLIII.E.41.b: apply knowledge of familiar language resources for linking ideas, events, or reasons (e.g., using connecting/transition words and phrases, such as meanwhile, however, on the other hand) to comprehending texts and writing increasingly cohesive texts

652CA5B516A24B0EA8DE5D0F8F02CF38.description: ESOLIII.E.41.a: express attitude and opinions with a variety of familiar modal expressions (e.g., possibly/likely, could/ would)

D2FF18BCD42441EA97D0AC43A9672868.description: ESOLIII.E.41: choose words and phrases to provide precise details, descriptions, comparisons, and ordered procedures

9EE8579253AC4B0D8F4D4B638BE425CE.description: ESOLIII.E.40: consult reference materials, both print and digital, to clarify the meaning or pronunciation of a word or determine the part of speech

6C0AAA1B25E148C3814E53318B6718B5.description: ESOLIII.E.39.e: combine clauses in a growing number of ways to create compound and complex sentences that make connections between and link concrete and abstract ideas, for example, to express a reason (e.g., He stayed at home on Sunday in order to study for Monday’s exam) or to make a concession (e.g., She studied all night even though she wasn’t feeling well)

5D6B161E8E6644AD9639EE47E7FC4BFA.description: ESOLIII.E.39.d: expand sentences with a growing variety of adverbials (e.g., adverbs, adverb phrases, prepositional phrases) to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause) about familiar or new activities or processes

C41EA2F9E0654620920513A26ED8DCBF.description: ESOLIII.E.39.c: expand noun phrases in a growing number of ways (e.g., adding adjectives to nouns, simple clause embedding) to create detailed sentences that accurately describe, explain, and summarize information and ideas on a variety of personal and academic topics

063E0E31061644F291AB06A565DE6346.description: ESOLIII.E.39.b: distinguish between passive and active voice

23C613BFE2584A768BB2B6A96EA7BD3E.description: ESOLIII.E.39.a: use a variety of verbs in different tenses (e.g., past, present, future, simple, progressive, perfect) appropriate to the text type and discipline to create a variety of texts that explain, describe, and summarize concrete and abstract thoughts and ideas

70E884A917F54E4EB360F6DF931ABE8A.description: ESOLIII.E.39: demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking

4ECE55C7C2AD45DC9FD9ED72A087C224.description: ESOLIII.D.38: evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different media (e.g., print or digital text, video, multimedia) to present a particular topic or idea

0791CE95206643A2B98A746ECC6BBA56.description: ESOLIII.D.37: include multimedia components and visual displays in presentations to clarify claims and findings and emphasize salient points

CAB24186B76B4EA1BB8C1B6D381B57BA.description: ESOLIII.D.36: plan and deliver a variety of oral presentations and reports on grade-appropriate topics that present evidence and facts to support ideas by using growing understanding of formal versus informal register

B74F37A98ACE4CFF95106CCD38DBA2E8.description: ESOLIII.D.35: adjust language choices according to the context (e.g., classroom, community), purpose (e.g., to persuade, to provide arguments or counterarguments), task, and audience (e.g., peers, teachers, guest lecturer)

26F54A0904D445FF8EC00BAEACC15739.description: ESOLIII.D.34: present claims and findings, emphasizing salient points in a focused, coherent manner with pertinent descriptions, facts, details, and examples; use appropriate eye contact, adequate volume, and clear pronunciation

7290CE4D55674922B4E09C7025DD2A44.description: ESOLIII.D.33: delineate a speaker’s argument and specific claims, evaluating the soundness of the reasoning and the relevance and sufficiency of the evidence

041E6429200E430091673D93B0DAC62B.description: ESOLIII.D.32: exchange oral and written information and ideas on topics related to contemporary events, history, and literature; demonstrate comprehension of these topics when presented through a variety of media

B2861F23C5EE473E84851D4B384C6BDC.description: ESOLIII.D.31: contribute to class, group, and partner discussions, sustaining conversations on a variety of age- and grade-appropriate, academic topics by following turn-taking rules, asking and answering relevant, on-topic questions, affirming others, providing additional, relevant information, and paraphrasing key ideas

D2E98678DC0049E2864E646E31373311.description: ESOLIII.D.30.j: negotiate with or persuade others in conversations (e.g., to provide counter-arguments) using a growing number of learned phrases (e.g., I see your point, but . . .) and open responses to express and defend nuanced opinions

F188DE36829E46178549BEF877D5BA10.description: ESOLIII.D.30.i: justify opinions and positions or persuade others by making connections between ideas and articulating relevant textual evidence or background knowledge

C62943FD4CAC404FB324F122256EBCC9.description: ESOLIII.D.30.h: synthesize vocabulary, phrases, and patterns in extended oral discourse

39CC49D7E7134201914349638D91F234.description: ESOLIII.D.30.g: demonstrate stamina when building ideas in a small group

C92D15EA6FC64CDFB1C9EF3FA42627A8.description: ESOLIII.D.30.f: interpret cause and effect from oral discourse; provide precise words and phrases to provide details, descriptions, classifications, comparisons, causes/effects, or procedures

5A6F928E85E94EAE95DD7FFB8D2726D5.description: ESOLIII.D.30.e: sequence processes, cycles, or procedures in short extended discourse

89492C64CD6348EB9DDF1664ADC9430A.description: ESOLIII.D.30.d: paraphrase and summarize content-related ideas in large and small groups

D5DF0180E3244D1E8CCA1398306E35F2.description: ESOLIII.D.30.c: ask clarifying questions in a respectful manner; validate the ideas of others; provide and receive constructive feedback from others tactfully

A639DBC7149E42E98A288B31C969634A.description: ESOLIII.D.30.b: pose and respond to questions in small group discussions

39A0020D3CBC4F84A616C47A463D9252.description: ESOLIII.D.30.a: identify details from oral discussions (e.g., when, who, where, what, and why)

36E107A0FDEE41238EB790054FDC27AF.description: ESOLIII.D.30: engage regularly, effectively, and extensively in a range of collaborative discussions (e.g., one-on-one, in groups, and teacher-led) with diverse partners on topics, texts, and issues, building on others’ ideas and expressing their own clearly

EFD738A852A24A29A46BC28C001681DF.description: ESOLIII.C.29: write routinely over extended time frames (e.g., time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (e.g., a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences

DEAF3978265448D8BB4CE4CC08731E20.description: ESOLIII.C.28: develop and strengthen writing as needed by participating in the writing process of planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, with input from peers and adults

F943B436AC974F17881235135F61F811.description: ESOLIII.C.27: utilize informal language from academic conversations to draft formal written texts

AB901FABBE4E42BFA3F2B4350B463991.description: ESOLIII.C.26: collaborate with peers to engage in increasingly complex, grade-appropriate written exchanges and writing projects, using technology as appropriate

AD5B2356F1F24D0CAB06E48473A6C327.description: ESOLIII.C.25.b: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

00F5F148B9174A9B8E653B9FF9F510AA.description: ESOLIII.C.25.a: gather relevant information from multiple print and digital sources, using search terms effectively; assess the credibility and accuracy of each source; and quote or paraphrase the data and conclusions of others while avoiding plagiarism and following a standard format for citation

C26CDDA5E7EF4D8EBA70B70068CFAEA1.description: ESOLIII.C.25: conduct short research projects to answer a question, drawing on several sources and generating additional related, focused questions for further research and investigation

88A5FACD5C7D4C31933A05EA4F18B0E3.description: ESOLIII.C.24: summarize opposing positions with evidence and evaluate and challenge evidence presented; summarize content-related material

5ECD8B06D2DB4030B2B5213B965A6A29.description: ESOLIII.C.23.e: integrate headings, introductory statements, and other features to organize text

C56D8C9F5BE642AF8DE3B7F7ED071BC5.description: ESOLIII.C.23.d: integrate images, diagrams, formulas, or charts to describe phenomena

9492E8A505C540A5A5CD276C9BEC534C.description: ESOLIII.C.23.c: explain ideas, phenomena, processes, and relationships within and across texts (e.g., compare/contrast, cause/effect, themes, evidence-based argument) based on close reading of a variety of grade-appropriate texts, presented in various print and multimedia formats, using increasingly detailed sentences, and an increasing variety of general academic and domain-specific words

7563FBA771174990848BDB36EAF69014.description: ESOLIII.C.23.b: write well-structured, coherent narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events, relevant descriptive details, and event sequences

2954B08DA86C4A06AAC58C66514A0EC3.description: ESOLIII.C.23.a: write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas, concepts, and information through the selection, organization, and analysis of relevant content

8FA98C94C0E24DD3B9E3DF70F54FF380.description: ESOLIII.C.23: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

55784859577F4ED2A2C10A52437281B0.description: ESOLIII.C.22: write arguments to support claims with clear reasons and relevant evidence

0D05826F3A5F44418D3FB99A02C7D799.description: ESOLIII.C.21: apply analysis of the organizational structure of different text types (e.g., how arguments are organized by establishing clear relationships among claims, counterclaims, reasons, and evidence)

E821DC8AB45641359E618207F4676589.description: ESOLIII.B.20.b: identify persuasive language across content areas

BEF62FC1C90145898984C4BBFBFDEAF4.description: ESOLIII.B.20.a: analyze how writers and speakers use language (e.g., specific word or phrasing choices) for specific purposes (e.g., to explain, persuade, entertain, etc.) depending on modality, text type, purpose, audience, topic, and content area

B7A40583A12B47108E0A236FC24BF497.description: ESOLIII.B.20: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone

F2C1E08B24A54029AF0E6089C06D1C5D.description: ESOLIII.B.19: identify any inferences that can be drawn from the text to support thesis and main idea

6860E5223D5D4B5EAE216F5C55E70811.description: ESOLIII.B.18: analyze how a text connects with other subject areas

614C5F6F918049D6A92B153CEFF14EA9.description: ESOLIII.B.17: demonstrate comprehension of current and historical events gained from a variety of written sources

8C005A76D2A342C994991F50B5CDCE0A.description: ESOLIII.B.16: read and comprehend nonfiction texts at the appropriate proficiency level, with scaffolding as needed

8DD89986C49948D8B565794F3AB2649C.description: ESOLIII.B.15: trace and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is sound and the evidence is relevant and sufficient to support the claims and recognize when irrelevant evidence is introduced

0D70315224794B9191298574E3E54ACF.description: ESOLIII.B.14: compare and contrast a text to an audio, video, or multimedia version of the text, analyzing how and why each medium’s portrayal of the subject differs (e.g., how the delivery of a speech affects the impact of the words)

D26C3020314B40D781EF8D3FBDF4F936.description: ESOLIII.B.13.b: analyze a case in which two or more texts provide conflicting information on the same topic and identify where the texts disagree on matters of fact or interpretation

89AA54808F19412D89EF8BC3D633F00A.description: ESOLIII.B.13.a: analyze how the author distinguishes his or her position from that of others

827088FB97AF4A5F8A06AFCDE72DF423.description: ESOLIII.B.13: determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how the author acknowledges and responds to conflicting evidence or viewpoints

C10769DD40124BDAB60E915D4C67A600.description: ESOLIII.B.12.d: analyze the organizational structure of different text types (e.g., how arguments are organized by establishing clear relationships among claims, counterclaims, reasons, and evidence) to comprehending texts

BC0D27441FF344E3A96AB97EA4BA160C.description: ESOLIII.B.12.c: explain how an author uses structure to persuade the reader (e.g., by providing well-worded evidence to support claims or connecting points in an argument in specific ways)

9A61AC71D49047BE80467C96E13A0C6A.description: ESOLIII.B.12.b: analyze in detail the structure of a specific paragraph, including how sentences work together to communicate a key concept

CE8FA4A55FBB4C8185829947F4CF2525.description: ESOLIII.B.12.a: analyze how an author uses the features of nonfiction text including headings, subheadings, and other features to communicate key concepts

540887F024D54B1F8022782A167BE22A.description: ESOLIII.B.12: analyze how an author organizes a text, including how the major sections contribute to the whole and to the development of the ideas

A208F2CE802549F5902F6A51B2003731.description: ESOLIII.B.11: cite several pieces of textual evidence to support the thesis and main ideas

6C4F5929D88E43E3BF1556FDBC5B376D.description: ESOLIII.B.10: determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including its relationship to supporting ideas; provide an objective summary of the text

BC9C68AC3E834ABB93C12582633CA98D.description: ESOLIII.A.9: compare and contrast the experience of reading a story, drama, or poem to listening to or viewing an audio, video, or live version of the text

209BD6F6B9D64E11A39FE7CD52ACEFF2.description: ESOLIII.A.8.a: compare/contrast fictional portrayals of a time or place

BE3A9B5B983344E1A51205C869954302.description: ESOLIII.A.8: analyze texts in different forms or genres (e.g., stories and poems, historical novels, fantasy stories, and traditional literature from different cultures), comparing and contrasting themes and topics

7A4713E6DD8D40C2930264181F0F2120.description: ESOLIII.A.7.b: identify various forms of poetry, including sonnet, and free verse

DE6B73BF5A254CBD9E3DAC4C285647B3.description: ESOLIII.A.7.a: identify the rhymes and other repetitions of sounds (e.g., alliteration) in a specific verse or stanza of a poem or section of a story or drama

0510D9B5EAF74D44A9B9D1BB651E00AD.description: ESOLIII.A.7: analyze the elements of poetry (including tone, metaphor, simile, form, alliteration, rhyme, imagery, symbolism, and theme) from a variety of cultures, languages, and historic periods

7E9B4FE0BBB34FCD99E1D495B0752F17.description: ESOLIII.A.6: read and comprehend literature, including stories, dramas, and poems at the appropriate proficiency level with teacher or peer guidance, collaboration, and/or scaffolding as needed

F6255A12E69440C1A37001293333B3C5.description: ESOLIII.A.5.c: use reference materials to determine the meaning of unknown words and those with multiple meanings

3C001829EB1E4BF298F17B1DC0283277.description: ESOLIII.A.5.b: use knowledge of morphology (e.g., affixes, Greek & Latin roots) to determine the meaning of unknown words in a text

3FDFFAF4F591482CB6BF5E20FEFD49E3.description: ESOLIII.A.5.a: determine figurative and connotative meanings in a text

7065BA5A29C34C41AE5566BAA01D77A8.description: ESOLIII.A.5: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text

268C1E2379464896ADBF384A06D01510.description: ESOLIII.A.4.d: gather textual evidence that demonstrates how an author develops character, plot, and conflict in a piece of literature

7202BE7AF5EC42DEBE50B318683D02CB.description: ESOLIII.A.4.c: explain how successful writers use elements of literature (e.g., dialogue, character development, plot, resolution)

37EA05EFCE74477A9ABAE04062A7E8B1.description: ESOLIII.A.4.b: analyze how dialogue or incidents in a story or drama propel the action, reveal aspects of a character, or provoke a decision

E08DDFF39B6D424086D91E88D0187672.description: ESOLIII.A.4.a: identify and analyze the author’s point of view and how it affects the progression of events

A2A463613C384A23B009301CEDF664BD.description: ESOLIII.A.4: analyze how particular elements of a story or drama interact (e.g., how setting shapes the characters or plot)

E3018D07209A4B2499127A7ADFCB5EC1.description: ESOLIII.A.3.b: use graphic organizers or notes to organize and write summaries of texts and experiences

5A40CD0D7AE8420A8F5E7AC5FDA47910.description: ESOLIII.A.3.a: write increasingly concise summaries of texts and experiences by using complete sentences and keywords

2ED1386E0B67475A97D9536C7CF6AF22.description: ESOLIII.A.3: provide an objective summary of a variety of literary texts

BBE769B3E03A4508B95E5EADD5ACD485.description: ESOLIII.A.2: determine a theme and/or central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text

255A4DE5CCE24CF0814A700B8DE2D02E.description: ESOLIII.A.1: cite the textual evidence that most strongly supports an analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text
